i could make stuff happen i was just

my company's building a computer around

i got to meet dave and i met dick who

and dick told me this really interesting

they had this operating system called

ada dicket promised their customers that

a four user system that would run this
ada

one computer and he just said well jeff

and being young and eager to jump in and

i'm pretty sure i could figure out how

i've been making only seven at my old

i gave my two weeks notice i bought this

back at school i was using this

vm 370 from ibm this was a really cool

as guests from what i can figure out ibm

no one really said it was impossible so

seems pretty reasonable
but then i find out they've never

single user mode they've got the generic

i don't care i'm going to make this work
i write the bootstrap code
i learn how to assemble my code and burn

the
the disc and for the serial devices this

it taught me all i needed to know about

the memory layout every bit of input and

it took me about six weeks to get to the

everything's actually looking pretty

if you know your history of

and he just kind of casually says well
this is going to
going to work right i actually mortgage

so the stakes have been raised just a

ed his house i've got to really make

so i've got a couple weeks still to go
i'm ready to take the next big step
i take that single user os and what i

i'm simply going to slice the memory

multitasking
i'm just gonna run four copies of the

i partition out the memory i remember
this very very elegant piece of code
that that had three nested loops that
set up all of the memory management
i used every data register and every

to make it happen i've got the memory
all set up
now i simply need to apportion the time
across those four operating systems
actually not too difficult at least at
least to me anyway so i set up this this
clock interrupt
every time an interrupt comes in i take
the running os
i save away all of its registers i pick
the next one that's about to run
i restore all of its registers and i
turn control over to that new os
i added a little bit of interrupt logic
to the driver so that the drivers
wouldn't step on each other
but kind of seemed pretty clean and
pretty straightforward
at the hardware level i had no debugger

i had no in-circuit emulator there was
no run time
so i had simply had to make all this

careful
and just got everything to the point
where i was very confident
that i was doing things in in the right
way get time to start testing it out
i started up and i had done things right

each of these different operating system
partitions had a separate copy of the os
you could log in from a serial terminal
you could
do all the usual os commands and you
could write code
and compile it and run it each fully
independent of the other three
so that would work for almost a half an

but then unfailingly one of these
os partitions would just crash but it

in a weird and totally irreproducible

so i'm looking at the code and can't

because
there's really not that many options
every time we go through the code
it's going through the same code i'm

if i'm not doing that exactly right it's

so i'm measuring and counting and i'm

millions upon millions of times
at this point within the company there

super abstract ada code it's so it's

82. i'm wandering through the streets

and i can't i think of a bunch of

i'm thinking i'm saving in the registers

those are really clear everything's set
i'm managing all the state the drivers
aren't getting in the way of each other
it it really has to be memory corruption
there's no other possibility here i've

step through that code in my head and

somewhere around three or four in the

it is memory corruption so i get this

and then i'm going to check for that

wait a couple hours until the the office
